text: - [Prasanna] Good morning, everyone.

Any enterprise data
platform is a crucial aspect
of any organization's technology landscape

that provides a central
repository for all kinds of data.

There are several benefits why
organizations choose to build
an enterprise data platform.
Overall, an enterprise data platform

yields organizations to
maximize the value of their data

by providing a unified
and centralized approach
to data management and analytics.

Building an enterprise
data platform on the cloud

has several benefits over
traditional on-premise solutions.

It provides scalability,
increased availability,
improves security,

integration with other cloud
services for analytics,
and several other benefits.
In this short video, I would like to show
how to build an enterprise data platform
with just a click of a button.
I am Prasanna Sridharan,

working as a Principal
Data Architect in AWS.

I want to introduce Atomix
and One Click Data Framework,
which enables enterprise customers
to build their data platform on the cloud
with just one click of a button,

which would otherwise take
months to years of effort
to build the same.
As the name suggests, with one click,

customers will be able to build
an end-to-end data platform

starting from data ingestion
from various sources,

data standardization,
building data lineage,
performing data governance,

and data sharing to multiple
other consumer accounts,

which enables data mesh
kind of an architecture

where multiple data
producers can share the data
to multiple other data consumers.
So with one click,
customers will be able to build
their entire lakehouse platform,
both data lake as well as data warehouse.
We'll go over a scenario
showing a journey of a data scientist
building a mission-learning model.

Here we have John, who
is a data scientist,

who wanted to build a
mission-learning model
based on customer spending habits.

So he wants to have access
to customer demographics data
and some transactions data

to know on what products
these customers spend on.
He goes into the enterprise data platform

and searches for the
customer demographics data
and customer transactions data.

He was able to find
customer transactions data
in one of the data warehouse table,
but he doesn't have access to that.
So he has to raise a request
to get access to the transactions table.

On the other hand, he
couldn't find any table
which contains customer demographics data
in the enterprise data platform.

But he knows that one of the
on-prem databases in MySQL
has got customer demographics information
in the customer master table.

First, he needs to bring
in the demographics data

from the on-prem database to
the enterprise data platform.
Even after bringing in the data,

he will not have access
to the table by default.
So he has to raise a request

to get access to the customer
demographics data as well.
Once the access goes through,
he'll be able to access these tables

from his own data science
account, which enables him

to build a mission-learning
model successfully.

The overall process of bringing
in the data from on-prem

and getting access would take
weeks to months of effort.
Using Atomix, John will be able to
bring in the customer demographics data
from on-prem MySQL database,

get access to the
customer demographics data
from the data lake,

get access to the
customer transactions data
from the data warehouse,

all of the above with just
one click of a button.
Let's get to the demo

and see how John performs
all the above actions
using Atomix.

John logs into the enterprise
data platform account
and search for customer demographics data
and customer transactions data

in both data lake as
well as data warehouse.
He couldn't find any database or tables
related to customers in the data lake
so he moves on to data warehouse

to check if he's able to find
anything related to customers.

He was able to find a table
related to customer transaction
but he couldn't find anything
related to customer demographics.

He's aware that one of the
on-prem database systems

have information related
to customer demographics.
He logs into the on-prem database
and finds a table called customer master,
which has got the demographics information
about all the customers.
Now you need to bring in this data

from the customer master to
the enterprise data platform
to develop this mission-learning model.
John logs into Atomix
so that he can raise a request
to bring in the customer master data
from the enterprise data platform.

Once he logs in, he sees
his status dashboard.

The dashboard displays the
number of objects or tables
that are brought into the data lake
from various source systems.
It displays the realtime progress

of all the batch processes
for the date selected.

The number of new objects
that were brought in
for the date selected,
number of objects ran,

the data is refreshed
from the source systems,

and its execution status
of those batch process.
The number of objects from the data lake

that was shared to multiple
other consumer accounts
for the date selected,

a number of objects
from the data warehouse

that were shared to
multiple other consumers
for the date selected.
So it's a one-stop dashboard
where we can get the entire picture
of the data lake platform.
When you click on the object count
or the object overview link,

it displays the details
for all the objects.

You'll be able to find the
source system, database, schema,
and other details from where the object
or table was brought in from.

When you click on any
of these object ID link,
you'll be able to find more details
about the object selected.
Some of the controls here are editable,
where you can modify and submit.
You can modify the compute capacity

or you could modify the
note type and submit.
The updated value would be referred to
in the subsequent execution of the object.
In the objects overview screen,

you'll be able to filter based
on the various attributes.
With multiple dynamic filters,
you'll be able to sort on any attributes.
You can also set your preferences

to show and hide attributes
and set your page size.

All these navigational
controls like dynamic filters,
sorting, pagination, and preferences

are available in all
the screens in Atomix.

When John searched for
a particular object,

object name called customers,
he couldn't find any.

So he clicks on the generic
manifest files link,
which opens up the onboarding form

where you can enter the
details of the object
that you want to bring in.

Currently, Atomix supports
these source types
from where you can bring in data from:
any of the flat files,

any on-prem RDBMS databases
like Oracle or SQL server
or MySQL or Postgres,

or any other databases
which are JDBC compatible.

You can bring in data from
Realtime Change Data Capture
from any of the on-prem RDBMS databases.

In our case, John is
trying to bring in data

from MySQL database, so he
chooses RDBMS batch option

which will display a simple
form where you need to feed in
the object details and submit.

He is trying to bring
in the data from MySQL
so he enters the source system name,
database name, schema name, object name,

schedule in which he
wants to refresh the data,
and few other information, and hit submit.

Once submitted, you will be
able to track the progress
of the data ingestion process

by either clicking on the
object onboarding summary screen

or clicking on the link
from the status dashboard.
All the necessary AWS resources

will be created during
object onboarding process
to bring in the object
from the on-prem source database.
Object onboarding somebody's screen
will display the overall status
of the object onboarding process.
Now the status is queued,
which will be picked up in a minute.
Let's refresh the screen.
Now the status has changed to running,

so the request is picked up
and the onboarding process
is in progress.

If you click on the
object onboarding link,
it will pull up the detail screen
where you find the step-by-step details
of the object onboarding process.
Every time you refresh,
you will see the progress of the batch.
It takes few minutes to complete
for the object onboarding process.
Now that it's complete,
the status of all these steps
have been changed to succeeded.

You can also see the status
in the summary as well,
which is succeeded.
You can click on the show button

to see an-eye level details
of the onboarding process
instead of going to detailed screen.

Now the object has been
onboarded successfully,

the object execution
process will be picked up.

The actual data will be
transferred from the on-prem source
to the enterprise data lake
during the object execution process.

Object execution screen will
display the overall status
of the object execution process.
Now the status is queued,
which will be picked up in a minute.
Now the status has changed to running,
so the request is picked up
and the execution process is in progress.
If you click on this object execution ID,
it will open up the detailed screen
where you'll be able to find

step-by-step details of
the execution process.
Every time you refresh the screen,

you'll be able to see the
progress of the batch.
Now that it is complete,

you can see the status
from the summary as well,
which should have changed to succeeded.
You can also click on the show

to see high-level details
of the execution process
instead of going to the previous screen.
Now we know that the customer master table
has been successfully brought
into the enterprise data platform.
John can now try accessing these tables
from the data science account.
John is in the data science account.
This is his mission-learning notebook
that is going to do the model training
and model development.

When he tries to query the
table from the customer master,

he is getting an invalid
request exception error

since he does not have
access to this table yet.

Let's query the customer
transaction table.

We got a similar error,
resource not found exception,
for the same reason,

that he does not have
access to these tables yet.
Let's go back to Atomix

and try to request
access for these tables.
I'm back to Atomix

and I am in the generate

Last time, John request
to onboard an object
from the on-prem system.

This time, since our objects
are already available
in enterprise data platform,

he needs to request
the consumption access.
Select the option object consumption.
You will see there are two types.
One for request access to the objects
that are there in the data lake,

and another one for requesting
access to the objects
that are there in the data warehouse.
Let's try to raise the access request
for the customer master table
which is there in the data lake.
Once the option data lake is selected,

fill up the necessary
information and submit.
We enter the database name,

the object name that he
wants to have access to,
the role that he'll be using to perform
his mission-learning exercise,

the account number from
which he will be performing
his mission-learning exercise.

Fill up all the necessary
details and click on submit.

Once submitted, you can monitor

by either clicking the data
lake access summary link

It works the same way as we saw

during the object onboarding
and execution process.
In the data lake access summary screen,

I filtered for the object
name as customer master.

The process has successfully
ran and status is succeeded.
You can click on the show button

to see the high-level
details for the progress,

or you can also click
on this permission ID,

which will give you the
step-by-step progress
of the process in the detailed screen.

John now has access to
the customer master table.

He now need to request for
customer transactions table
which is there in the data warehouses.
He has to repeat the same step
similar to the previous access request.

He has to go back to the

click on the object consumption

and select the source
type as data warehouse

Similar to the data lake request,

you will have to enter the
the source database name,

for which John is

along with producer information,
consumer information,
and hit submit.

Once submitted, you can

of the request

by either clicking the data
warehouse access summary link
or the link from the status dashboard.
It works the same way as we saw
in the data lake access request process.

In the data warehouse

The process has successfully ran
and the status is succeeded.
You can click on the show button

step-by-step progress
of the process.

John now has access to
both customer master
as well as customer transactions table.

He should now be able
to access these tables

and build his mission-learning
model successfully.

So he's querying the
customer master table.

He is able to successfully

Now that he has access

So using Atomix, John was able to bring in

get access to the

get access to the

He doesn't have to write
